description: From Middle English clarifien, from Old French clarifiier, from Latin clārificō, clārificāre; clārus (“clear”) + faciō, facere (“make”). Semantically clear +‎ -ify.

verbs.description: clarify (third-person singular simple present clarifies, present participle clarifying, simple past and past participle clarified)

entries.meaning: (of liquids, such as wine or syrup) To make clear or bright by freeing from feculent matter.
To make clear or easily understood; to explain in order to remove doubt or obscurity.
(ergative) To grow or become clear or transparent; to become free from feculent impurities, as wine or other liquid under clarification.
examples: Leave the wine for 24 hours and it will clarify.

entries.meaning: (ergative) To grow clear or bright; to clear up.
